metadata.title: Water extract of pomegranate ash as waste-originated biorenewable catalyst for the novel synthesis of chiral <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>‑butanesulfinyl aldimines in water

Water extract of pomegranate ash as waste-originated biorenewable catalyst for the novel synthesis of chiral tert‑butanesulfinyl aldimines in water Bandameeda Ramesh Naidu Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Writing – review & editing Jangam Lakshmidevi Investigation Methodology Bukke Siva Sankar Naik Investigation Methodology Katta Venkateswarlu Conceptualization Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Supervision Project administration Writing – review & editing ⁎ Laboratory for Synthetic & Natural Products Chemistry, Department of Chemistry, Yogi Vemana University, Kadapa 516005, India Laboratory for Synthetic & Natural Products Chemistry Department of Chemistry Yogi Vemana University Kadapa 516005 India Laboratory for Synthetic & Natural Products Chemistry, Department of Chemistry, Yogi Vemana University, Kadapa 516005, India ⁎ Corresponding author. The renewable materials catalyzed reactions in aqueous media is urgently needed and highly fascinating task in the current state of organic synthesis. Here, we report a novel and sustainable protocol for the biorenewable, waste-originated water extract of pomegranate ash (WEPA) catalyzed condensation reaction of tert‑butanesulfinamides and aldehydes in water to produce chiral tert‑butanesulfinyl aldimines (tBSAIs) in high yields. The products are separated by filtration and purified by recrystallization; avoids the extraction and column chromatographic separation steps. The reaction was performed with high yields in several consecutive recycles of the catalyst and medium, and further this method is highly effective for the multi-gram scale synthesis of tBSAIs. The application of biorenewable catalyst, added metal/catalyst free conditions, absence of volatile organic solvents and additives, vast substrate feasibility, economical profiles, easy operation, reusability of the catalyst, large scale viability, non-chromatographic purification of products and tremendous future perspective are the sparkling insights of this development. Graphical abstract A novel and versatile protocol has been developed for the synthesis of tert‑butanesulfinyl aldimines using water extract of pomegranate ash (WEPA) as catalyst in water. Image, graphical abstract Keywords WEPA Renewable catalyst Water Tert-butanesulfinyl aldimines Excellent reusability Non-chromatographic purification 1 Introduction The implementation of natural resources based (biorenewable) materials/feed stocks in synthetic chemistry is eco-promising and highly sustainable technique in minimizing the use of depleting petroleum originated chemicals [1-3]. The use of waste derived products for significant chemical transformations is further fascinated by the eventual decrease of environmental pollution [4-6]. In this context, the aqueous extracts of organic wastes are highly captivating and play a vital role in multifarious organic transformations like CC couplings [7-10], ipso-functionalization of aromatic compounds [11-13], Michael addition [14], aromatic bromination [15], hydrothiolation of alkynes [16], organic disulfides synthesis [17], isoindoline-1,3-diones preparation [18], nanoparticles preparation [19,20], synthesis of bisindolylmethanes [21], biodiesel production [22] and synthesis of coumarins [23]. These extracts are also beneficial due to the utilization of water as media which reveal the bioorganic synthesis, since water is the nature's preferred solvent by which it has been optimized from millions of years the highly selective reactions to produce ultrapure materials at mild conditions [3,24,25]. Moreover, water is non-flammable, non-volatile, safe, inexpensive, highly abundant, and makes the synthetic operations very simple and sometimes with highly selectivity [26,27]. Modern organic synthesis based on volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is the detrimental in environmental pollution and the use of nature's preferred solvent such as water and(or) biorenewable materials can undoubtedly reduce the environmental pollution [2,3,27]. The azomethines or imines are versatile and highly reactive substrates in organic synthesis. In this field, chiral sulfinyl imines are highly valuable due to their efficient electrophilic character than alkyl or arylimines, strong stereodirecting capacity, and easy installation and removal [28-30]. These imines readily react with various organometallic species, other nucleophiles and reducing agents to give nitrogen-containing compounds [28,29,31]. Chiral pure tert‑butanesulfinyl imines are the key substrates in the synthesis of several biopotent complex alkaloids including anticancer active (-)-vindorosine [32], antileishmanii (-)-harmicine [33], human neuronkinin-1 substance P receptor antagonist (+)-CP-99,994 [34], cytotoxin theopederin D [35], serotonin 5-HT4 agonist SC-53,116 [36], anticancer agent (-)-normalindine [37], nicotinic agonist (-)-epiquinamide [38] and antimalarial agent (+)-febrifugine [39] (Fig. 1 ). The available strategies for the construction of sulfinyl imines include i. oxidations of sulfenimines [40], ii. reductive imination of nitriles with menthylsulfinates [41], iii. condensations of sulfinamides with carbonyl compounds [42-47], iv. oxidative coupling of benzylic compounds with sulfinylamides [48-50] and v. deprotective condensation of acetals with sulfinamides [51]. Among these, the condensation strategy of carbonyl compounds with sulfinamides is simple and easily accessed with the readily available substrates [44]. This transformation occurs under acid or base catalysis and the base catalyzed reactions are underdeveloped. NaOH/tBuOK-CH3OH [52], Cs2CO3 CH2Cl2 [53], PhCH2ZnBr-THF [54], DBU-DMF [55] and pyrrolidine-CH2Cl2–4 Å MS [43] systems are reported in base catalyzed category. As evidenced, these often required dry conditions, added organic or inorganic bases, application of volatile/toxic/unconventional solvents [43,52-55]. Consequently, the wide spread applicability of chiral tBSAIs in synthesizing complex alkaloids and chiral amines, the development of mild protocols are highly desirable under base mediated conditions. This strategy may be useful for the substrates with acid sensitive groups, since the acid catalysts are widely used for the synthesis of tBSAIs [29,31,44,45]. The application of biorenewable materials as catalyst in aqueous media with a generalized profile is highly challenging and very fetching for this purpose. Our recent studies denoted a critical role of WEPA in Pd-catalyzed CC couplings [9,10,56-58] was encouraged us to exploit its capability in added catalyst free process and found its successful aptness in the bromination of (hetero)aromatics [15]. Here we report an effective method employing WEPA as sustainable catalyst in water for the preparation of chiral tBSAIs and the high yields of the products were found despite the difficulty of imine synthesis in aqueous media [51,59]. As far as we are aware, no report is appeared on the base catalyzed synthesis of chiral tBSAIs in aqueous media. The application of biorenewable base is reinforced by several environmental benefits. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Pomegranate peels were derived from a fresh collection of pomegranates. All the analytical grade substrates used for this method are purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Spectrochem and Alfa Aesar. Improvement in reactions was ensured by thin layer chromatography (TLC) using precoated silica gel (60 F254 - Merck) plates and the reactants and products are visualized through UV light. The 1H/13C NMR spectra were obtained using NMR spectrometer operating at 400/100 MHz in CDCl3 using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as reference standard. Chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in parts per million (ppm) and coupling constants (J) in hertz (Hz). Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) data and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images are obtained employing JEOL JST-IT-500 system. JASCO P-2000 polarimeter has been employed for obtaining optical rotation. FT-IR spectrum of WEPA was obtained using Bruker ALPHA II ECO-ATR compact FT-IR spectrometer and an X-ray diffraction (XRD) study of WEPA was conducted using Rigaku MiniFlex600 instrument. 2.2 Preparation of WEPA A fresh collection of pomegranates are used to obtain pomegranate peel. The peel was cut into small pieces was shade dried and the dried peels are made into ash by burning in open-air. A suspension of 10 g of pomegranate peel ash in distilled water (100 mL) was stirred at ambient conditions for 3 h. The resultant heterogeneous mixture was filtered to get a pale yellow extract, termed WEPA [9]. 2.3 General experimental procedure In a typical experiment, a solution of aldehyde (1) (1 mmol), (R)‑tert-butanesulfinamide (2) (1.3 mmol), WEPA (0.5 mL), EtOH (0.3 mL) and deionized water (4 mL), was subjected for stirring at 75 °C in a water bath. After finishing (as noticed by using TLC) the reaction mixture was added 5 mL of cold water and precipitated product was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with cold water and recrystallized using a mixture of water and ethanol. Fig. 2 shows the significant steps in the synthesis of tBSAI, 3a from 4-nitrobenzaldehyde (1a) and 2. Structures of imines (3) were ascertaining from their spectral (1H & 13C NMR and MS) data (please see at Supporting Information) which resembles the reported data. 2.4 Procedure for multi-gram scale preparation of tBSAIs Added 10 ml of WEPA, 6 mL EtOH and 70 mL of deionized water to a mixture of 3.02 g of 1a (20 mmol) and 2.66 g of 2 (22 mmol). The resultant mixture was subjected for vigorous stirring at 75 °C in water bath for 50 min, cooled the reaction mixture to room temperature (rt) was added 80 mL of ice cold water. The precipitated imine, 3a was filtered, washed with cold water and recrystallized using 1:1 mixture of water and ethanol to obtain 4.83 g of 3a (95%). 2.5 Reusability study of catalyst The reaction mixture of 1a and 2 after completion of the reaction (Section 2.3) was evaporated to remove EtOH and extracted with ethyl acetate for the separation of imine, 3a. The resultant aqueous portion was evaporated in rotary evaporator for the removal of ethyl acetate was added 1a (1 mmol), 2 (1.3 mmol), EtOH (0.3 mL) and the reaction was carried out as described in the general procedure (Section 2.3). 3 Result and discussion Our recent X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), EDX and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis of WEPA indicated that it contains potassium oxide and chlorides in large quantities, sodium oxide, sulfur trioxide, magnesium oxide, calcium oxide, alumina and silica in small quantities along with other non-metallic and metallic species in ppm level [9,56-58]. The XRD patterns of WEPA (Fig. 3 a) signify the existence of carbon, oxygen, magnesium, potassium, chlorine and calcium. The peaks in XRD at 2θ values 28.8°, 31.24°, 32.35°, 39.66°, 40.38° and 50.08° indicates the presence of K2O and K2CO3 in the cubic face (JCPDS file no. 77–2176 and 87‐0730) [22,60,61] in WEPA. It also showed a peak at 25.45° represents MgO (ICDS ID 181,460). Two peaks at 36.3° and 41.46° represents CaO [62]. The peaks at 2θ = 29.56°, 58.48° and 66.34° represents KCl [63] and peaks at 26.76° and 32.06° indicates CaCl2 [64] in WEPA. This XRD study of WEPA concurs with our previous XRF and XPS analysis [9,56-58]. In FT-IR spectrum of WEPA (Fig. 3b), the shoulder peak at 2332 cm-1 is corresponds to the absorption of atmospheric CO2 on the metal cations [65]. Absorption peaks at 1605, 1443 and 1377 cm-1 are corresponds to C = O groups in WEPA [65]. The absorption peaks at 808, 1050 and 1118 are due to the K-O bond [66]. The absorption at 1377 cm-1 is due to the presence of OH on the surface of metal oxides [65]. Ca-O symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrational peaks are observed at 667, 701 and 1605 cm-1 [66]. The vibration band at 876 cm−1 indicates Mg-O-Mg interaction [65]. The SEM image of powder obtained after the evaporation of water of WEPA showed uniform and defined sheets like structure (Fig. 3c). The EDX analysis of freshly prepared WEPA (Fig. 3d) also indicates the presence of potassium, magnesium, chlorine and calcium along with carbon and oxygen. The relative amounts of these elements are comparable with our recent reports [9,57] and hence the composition of WEPA is evidently constant. Furthermore, the titration experiments of WEPA using oxalic acid showed the presence of 0.09 N bases in WEPA. At the beginning of the study of WEPA catalysis in the synthesis of tBSAIs, the reaction of 1a (1 mmol) with 2 (1.3 mmol) using WEPA (0.1 mL) and water (4 mL) has been observed to form 7% of aldimine, 3a in 12 h (Table 1 , entry 1). The reaction of 1a and 2 was provided 22% (5 h), 50% (3 h) and 50% (3 h) of 3a at 65 °C, 75 °C and 85 °C (Table 1, entries 2–4), hence this method is effective at 75 °C. Formation of 3a with 65% and 72% in 3 h was observed by increasing the amount of catalyst (WEPA) to 0.2 mL and 0.3 mL (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). The addition of 0.2 mL, 0.3 mL and 0.4 mL of EtOH to the reaction of 1a and 2 using 0.3 mL of WEPA and 4 mL of water delivered 3a with 84%, 88% and 88% in 2 h (Table 1, entries 7–9). The increase of catalyst quantity to 0.4 mL, 0.5 mL and 0.6 mL using 0.3 mL of EtOH was resulted 3a in 93% (1 h), 99% (0.75 h) and 98% (0.75 h) (Table 1, entries 10–12). These studies indicated the WEPA catalyzed synthesis of tBSAIs require 0.5 mL of WEPA, 0.3 mL of EtOH, 4 mL of water and 75 °C (Table 1, entry 11). Other aqueous extracts of agro-waste ashes such as water extract of banana (WEB) [7], water extract of rice straw ash (WERSA) [67] and water extract of lemon shell ash (WELSA) [68] are also studied for the current chiral tBSAI synthesis (Table 1, entries 13–15), but WEPA shows best results among these extracts. The presence of oxides, hydroxides and carbonates of metals such as potassium, sodium, magnesium, aluminum, etc. along with non-metallic oxides in the ashes gives the basicity to their aqueous extracts. The pH of WEB, WERSA, WEPA and WELSA are reported as 10.08 [69], 10–12 [70], 11.7–12.1 [9] and 11.24 [68]. The presence of high pH along with the large quantity of potassium in the form of its oxide, carbonate and chloride may be the reason to show high activity for WEPA over the other studied extracts. The necessity of WEPA for the present synthesis of tBSAIs has also noticed by conducting the reaction of 1a and 2 in water or EtOH, which shows no progress of the reaction in the absence of WEPA (Table 1, entries 16 and 17). The optimized green reaction conditions are then studied for the implementation to a variety of (hetero)aryl aldehydes (Table 2 ). Benzaldehyde and mono substituted aryl aldehydes with electron donating groups such as methyl (p-), methoxy (p-), hydroxy (p-, m- and o-), benzyloxy (m-) and bromo (p- and o-) are provided excellent yields of tBSAIs (91–98%) in 1.5–2 h regardless of their position on aromatic moiety (Table 2, products, 3b-3j). Disubstituted 3,4-dimethylbenzaldehyde also provided imine, 3k with 93% yield in 2.5 h. The aryl aldehydes with electron withdrawing substituents like chloro (p- and m-), fluoro (p-) and nitro (p- and o-) are observed as good substrates under present WEPA catalyzed conditions and gave tBSAIs with 93–99% yields in 0.75 - 2 h (Table 1, entry 11 and Table 2, products 3l-3o). The bulky aryl aldehydes; 1-naphthaldehyde and anthracene-9-carboxaldehyde gave 93% and 94% yields of imines 3p and 3q in 2 h. α,β-Unsaturated aldehydes such as trans-cinnamaldehyde and citral (mixture of geranial and neral) and aliphatic aldehydes such as n-octanal and 3-phenylpropanal are also produced high yields (92–97%) of tBSAIs, 3r-3 u in 1.5–2.5 h. The successful aptness of WEPA catalyzed process to an array of heteroaryl aldehydes is the significant development of this method. Furfural, thiophene-2-carboxaldehyde, indole-3-carboxaldehyde and imidazole-2-carboxaldehyde are provided 91–93% of chiral imines, 3v-3y in 2–2.5 h. Some of the reported methods are inefficient in the synthesis of tBSAIs of heteroaryl aldehydes. For example, CuSO4 catalyzed imination provides only 40% of sulfinylimine with furfural [71]. Low to moderate yields of imination products (58–76% or 30–56%) are reported using Yb(OTf)3 [72] or I2 [47] as catalyst. The chiral imination of biomass derivative, acetylhydroxymethylfurfural (AcHMF) is another sustainable development of this protocol and AcHMF gave 91% of chiral imine, 3z in 2 h. The acetyl group of AcHMF was not hydrolysed during the imination process and hence it is an example of high functional group tolerance under base (WEPA) catalysis in water. The derivative of AcHMF may be utilized for further transformation into chiral natural/unnatural compounds. The measured optical rotation value of 3a, [α]D 25 - 66.26 (c = 0.1, CHCl3) has been found to be closer to its reported optical rotation values as [α]D 25 - 64.64 (c = 0.1, CHCl3) [44] and [α]D 25 - 70 (CHCl3) [47], and hence no racemization is occurred under the present bio-derived base catalyzed sulfinylimination reaction of aldehydes in water. WEPA catalyzed synthesis of tBSAIs has also been investigated for the reusability of the catalyst-media system using separated catalyst (WEPA)-water after the completion of the reaction of 1a and 2 (Section 2.5), and found to form 3a with 99%, 97%, 97%, 94% & 92% of yield in 45 min during 1st - 5th cycles (Fig. 4 ). This study suggests the high reusability of household waste derived catalyst, WEPA. The mechanism of WEPA catalyzed preparation of tBSAIs in water (Scheme 1 ) is seems to be comparable with the tBuOK catalyzed mechanism of synthesis of sulfinyl aldimines was proposed by Ardej-Jakubisiak et al. [52]. The base of WEPA (mostly KOH since the large quantity of K2O present in evaporated WEPA [56-58] indicates its existence in water as KOH) may initiate the nucleophilic reaction of chiral sulfinamide, 2 and aldehyde, 1 to form α-sulfinylamino alkoxide, B via an intermediate, A. Transitory species B regenerates base (BM) and α-sulfinylaminol C. Intermediatory aminol C gives tBSAI (3) on elimination of water. The regenerated base can involve in further catalytic cycle which was also confirmed from the high reusability of the catalytic media (Fig. 4). Several reported methods of synthesis of tBSAIs suffers with certain drawbacks such as difficulty in the separation/removal of catalyst, requirement of volatile organic solvents as reaction medium and inert atmosphere, necessity of 1–3 equivalents of catalysts and column chromatographic separation of products [44,45]. These processes require the chemical substances based on petrochemicals are obviously responsible for the generation of unwanted waste. The present protocol, on the other hand, involve the use of waste derived catalyst can minimize the generation of waste and is based on biorenewable source. The catalyst in the present study can be separated by filtration and the tBSAIs are purified by recrystallization technique instead of column chromatography, enable the elimination of toxic/volatile organic solvents required in extraction and chromatography process. This method is also successful for the multi-gram scale synthesis (~4.8 g) of tBSAIs (Section 2.4) is the additional asset of this protocol. Finally to explore the applicability; a variety of pomegranates including Dholka, Ruby, Ganesh and Arakta varieties along with a local cultivation variety were used to prepare WEPA was studied for the present protocol using 1a and 2. Surprisingly, all these pomegranate ashes based aqueous extracts displayed similar results. The WEPA obtained by heating the aqueous suspension of pomegranate ash at 80 °C for 3 h also showed the identical results as the WEPA prepared at ambient conditions (Section 2.2). Therefore, the variety of pomegranate or the method of preparation of WEPA displays negligible influence on the present protocol. 4 Conclusions In summary a practical system has been developed for the aqueous extract of waste pomegranate peel ash catalyzed synthesis of chiral tBSAIs. The present sustainable method showed its successful applicability to a variety of aldehydes based on aryl, heteroaryl, alkyl and alkenyl moieties. This method is also applicable to biomass derivative, AcHMF and displayed high functional group tolerance. The successful applicability of this protocol to multi-gram scale synthesis of tBSAIs, high reusability of the renewable catalyst, up to 99% of yields of tBSAIs, application of water as reaction media, avoid of depleting materials (petrochemical/metal) based external catalysts and volatile organic solvents, non-chromatographic purification of tBSAIs, and easy separation of the catalyst are the highlights of this development. This method is also beneficial by the application of waste-originated material to state-of-the-art chemical transformation and hence it is a significant example for the waste utilization. coredata.dc:description: The renewable materials catalyzed reactions in aqueous media is urgently needed and highly fascinating task in the current state of organic synthesis. Here, we report a novel and sustainable protocol for the biorenewable, waste-originated water extract of pomegranate ash (WEPA) catalyzed condensation reaction of tert‑butanesulfinamides and aldehydes in water to produce chiral tert‑butanesulfinyl aldimines (tBSAIs) in high yields. The products are separated by filtration and purified by recrystallization; avoids the extraction and column chromatographic separation steps. The reaction was performed with high yields in several consecutive recycles of the catalyst and medium, and further this method is highly effective for the multi-gram scale synthesis of tBSAIs. The application of biorenewable catalyst, added metal/catalyst free conditions, absence of volatile organic solvents and additives, vast substrate feasibility, economical profiles, easy operation, reusability of the catalyst, large scale viability, non-chromatographic purification of products and tremendous future perspective are the sparkling insights of this development.
coredata.dc:title: Water extract of pomegranate ash as waste-originated biorenewable catalyst for the novel synthesis of chiral tert‑butanesulfinyl aldimines in water
